displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: that much of a difference. So… Family Member: Is that the only lymph node involved? Doctor: That’s visible right now. Family Member: Oh, okay. So that’s the same one that’s been there? Doctor: Previously, before we started, I think there were more than one that we were seeing. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: Before we started on the Xtandi and everything, you know the study. But since then we really barely even see those lymph nodes and even so they’ve been so small. Family Member: Great. Patient: So does that indicate that what your husband did worked? Family Member: Well no, that’s the bone scan. Doctor: No it doesn’t.

Patient: Oh man, come on listen you gotta understand something doc, you got to be able to share the wealth and be a cheerful giver. DOC; Mm, hmm. Doctor: Yeah, we’re gonna definitely go over the results don’t you worry. Patient: Yeah. yeah. Doctor: They’re the spots in the back. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It still is that one area. Patient: It, it it ain’t moved at all? Doctor: No. Patient: That’s good. Doctor: I’m very glad just like W___ that it’s not in your hip. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: You already say Dr. P___ a while ago do you remember that for your back. Patient: Yes. Yes.

Patient: Yes. Just Lupron Doctor: And, today, did you get blood drawn? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, because I haven’t seen that PSA. Healthcare Professional: don’t have a PSA. Doctor: How long ago was it? Healthcare Professional: How long ago, I haven’t checked with Doctor: No. How long ago was his previous one? Do we know? Healthcare Professional: It was in July, it was four point two. Doctor: July…So, it’s been Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Two months almost. Okay. I’m going to plan for doing repeat scans. Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: I’ve been praying that… Doctor: We removed it and the fact that we removed it may minimize the reoccurrence. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So we’ll see. Patient: Um hmm. Well that’s why I want to go that route you know. Doctor: Yeah and you did the right thing. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Because if you had uh advanced disease it’s better to take it out first and then give radiation therapy as opposed to getting radiation therapy and then doing surgery. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The surgery is much more difficult, the side effects are more prevalent - Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - in patients who’ve had radiation therapy followed by surgery.

Patient: Hello. Doing good. Doctor: Doing okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Now you had a bone scan in between. Patient: I have the disc. Doctor: Do you have it? Okay. I need it. chuckles]] Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Alright I was wondering if uh… Patient: How about the CAT scan? Doctor: CAT scan I just called them. Patient: Sure. Doctor: They’re still loading the images. So they said they’ll let me know in a few minutes once it’s ready. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: But there is a newer hormonal therapy that also we can consider for you. Now that is sort of an earlier phase trial, so it’s a phase one trial. Okay. But the advantage is that we’ve already been through a number of the dosing levels. So typically a phase one trial is where you’re getting something very new that’s worked amazingly well in the lab that now you’re testing in people. So the first few dose levels really are trying to see what kind of side effects and what dose level really has… Patient: Sure. Doctor: But you’ll have some long days and things like that, you would have the hotel and mileage covered you know same as this study for that matter. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. (clears throat) Doctor: So those things would be covered, but it is a matter of whether you’re willing to come back and forth. Patient: Well I guess... Family Member: How long would we have to do that for that just out of curiosity? Doctor: It’s a, I’ll give you the exact… Doctor: Yeah but it’s more for the monitoring and because it’s a phase one trial it’s a little bit more closer monitoring. At least the first few weeks. After that it goes down to once a month once we sort of get the comfort level that you’re tolerating it okay, we know all the PKs and the blood level things are done, then it becomes much easier schedule. Family Member: What are the, how often are you talking about? A couple times a week or? Doctor: Well the first few weeks it will be about once a week or so or once every couple of weeks after a little while. And then after the first couple of months it goes to like I said once every four weeks.

Patient: I’m doing a lot. Doctor: And, uh, that, we have to be really careful about because I don’t want that to ruin your quality of life. But, I think for the most part, it’s more just gut/GI-ish stuff. So, this lack of appetite, and some people might be, like, “Wow, my stomach actually, you know, doesn’t feel good.” To, “I’ve got diarrhea or nausea.” So, all of that could lead to dehydration. You know, like, we just have to be super on top of that. Patient: Sure. Doctor: To make sure you don’t fall off the grid. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And it cannot substitute as a weight loss plan. Doctor: Let me just say it for the record. Patient: Well, yeah. We’re working on that part of it. Family Member: Yes. We are.

Patient: Okay, Alright Doctor: It really is and whether we pick chemo as the next step and sort of, you know, we say kind of learn out way through it, it will depend on how we fare. Hi, J____. What’s happening. Patient: Hi. Healthcare Professional: I know you wanted me to try to get the CT Doctor: Oh Healthcare Professional: and the report right now so I’m just gonna Doctor: Oh like for July? Healthcare Professional: Yes. So, if you can sign and date, I’m sorry to interrupt you, Doctor: No, no no Healthcare Professional: but I figured if I can get it while… Doctor: J____ is like Speedy Gonzales. She’s like let’s roll, let’s roll. Healthcare Professional: It’s really so I don’t forget it later.

Patient: Uh hum, okay. Doctor: So if the placebo is a non-starter for you, then we skipped that as an option. But again just thinking broad terms first before we get into those details. Just thinking in broad terms so push off the for hormone therapy for a while and do a targeted radiotherapy instead. Or whether you feel that you just want to go ahead and give the hormone therapy to increase the chances of that lasting as long as possible or do some remission that lasts Patient: And yeah, but the way I’m going, I’d be the one in three. (laughs) Doctor: Okay. Patient: If I had it the other way I would have won the lottery. Doctor: I hear you. I hear you. Patient: So thank you very much. Healthcare Professional: So uhm, how are you feeling? You got a lot of side effects from this. Patient: Well, uhm, with me as far as the medication I was on the worst part of it was I think the joints at first, but then it became progressively better. Healthcare Professional: Okay. Patient: To where once you know I guess I was on the medication long enough, that totally disappeared. But it for a while there it was just crazy. Healthcare Professional: You still have it. Right. Do you still feel it at all or?

Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: What’s your name? Family Member: K___ P____. He probably wouldn’t remember me. Doctor: I don’t know, he sometimes tends to remember a lot of the people he did… Family Member: Is he still in radiation oncology here? Doctor: He is. He just started back here within the last year. Before that he was at other hospitals. Family Member: Uh huh. Doctor: So yeah. Family Member: That’s great. Doctor: Alright. Family Member: Thank you, thank you again. Doctor: That is amazing. Small world right. Family Member: Yeah. (Laughs)

Patient: No. Family Member: No. Patient: No. Uh-uh. No. We, we had to drive that far to get there, but- Doctor: Did you stay like in a hotel or where did you stay at? Family Member: It was in a hotel. Then they get the bus to pick up at the hotel, then it takes you to the, uh, park, and then you get in this- Patient: You get in those little trucks. Family Member: Open trucks. Doctor: I have a patient, one of my patients is a guy with a lot of money, and he and his wife do this. But, you know, they do it like only people with a lot of money can do it. Patient: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: And he’s like, oh, yeah, we’re going and we stay in these tents. Patient: Oh, you can. Doctor: And his wife’s like, yeah, they’re not really tents, though. They like have king-size bed. You know? They’re like-

Family Member: In other words, when he eats it’s not going to be as wonderful. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: One of the things you enjoy. Doctor: But you know, if that's bad and we stop it and quality of life's terrible anymore Family Member: Well, with this neuropathy would this be something that would prevent him from being on this trial. Doctor: Well, you know, it’s yes, in the sense- Family Member: He definitely has it? Doctor: Right. If it's bad enough where you can't button, your shirt or you're constantly dropping things- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -or you're burning yourself or you're tripping all the time, that- Patient: My neuropathy is xxx. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. And you know, are you are you falling? Patient: No.

Patient: Yeah, yeah, at the same time, so Doctor: Yeah so hopefully that will put money in the bank and back in two days for your calcium and doing all the right thigns to keep your bones strong. Patient: Yeah Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Great I’ll let you head out and uh we’ll get these things off Patient: Happy New Year! Doctor: Yeah, Happy New Year to you as well.

Patient: Right. No. Doctor: No, no, no, right, because you don’t know how you’re going to react. Most people just get sleepy and want to take a nap and then they feel better but everyone’s different. Okay? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Make a copy of this and then. Oh yeah, go ahead. Family Member: Is Provenge off the table? Doctor: Provenge is off the table in the sense that your PSA is um too high I think but more importantly that you have pain. You know, Provenge is good with, it’s kind of like your asymptomatic, you’re doing great, you have a couple spots, your PSA is less than thirty. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You know, that’s not you and it kind of, you know, we were hoping with a little bit more time away from the Xtandi that that would have been you Patient: Right. Doctor: but that’s not the way you’re declaring yourself so, no, it won’t help. Patient: Okay. That’s no problem. Doctor: Yeah, we just need to move on to something a little bit more powerful. That is powerful in the right setting. You know, kind of like you’re almost like you have the flu and then I come around hey, did you want that flu shot, I’m kind of in the middle of it so no point whereas if this was a few months ago and it’s before flu season then it’s hey, it’s time for the flu shot. Okay, I’ll get it before I’m actually having the flu and the symptoms. Patient: That reminds me of another question.

Patient: Right. Doctor: that’s just too time consuming especially based on where you guys live and so on. Um but, in reviewing your scans it looks like it’s just all in your bones and not thank goodness in the organs or anywhere else. So, there is a liquid radiation that’s available for patients who have, Healthcare Professional: No its okay, I decided to come on in here. Doctor: We were just talking about radium um which is that liquid radiation that only patients who have stuff in their bones not liver or anywhere else would kind of be the right patient to get that medication and that’s like a one-minute injection that the radiation oncology doctors did once a month Patient: Okay. Doctor: and they do that six months so once a month for six months and that’s been shown to help people live longer and that’s actually FDA approved. So, one could run that through the insurance, you know get treated, and be on your way. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The good thing about that in addition to the survival is you have pain relief with that. So, actually if you didn’t have any pain, I couldn’t get that cleared through insurance because they only want people who have discomfort and pain. I’m not saying you have to be writhing on the floor Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: but you have to sort of say oh, yeah, I get pain so, you know, I know I have cancer. Um, but you’re actually a good candidate for that. You’re otherwise all your blood counts and everything is also good because if you were already coming in here with low white cells or low red cells you wouldn’t be great but you don’t have that problem. So, Patient: Okay. Doctor: maybe the next step should be this medicine called Xofigo which, you know, we can have a side effects sheet given to you. We have to run it through insurance. Patient: Okay.
